description: start-stop-daemon - start and stop system daemon programs

global_flags.description: This option  will  force  start-stop-daemon  to fork before starting the process, and force it into the background.
This is done after the chroot if  the  -r|--chroot  option  is  set.   When  not specified,  start-stop-daemon  will  change  directory  to the root directory before starting the process.
directory  and  chroot to root before starting the process. Please note that the pidfile is also written after the chroot.

to  this username/uid before starting the process.  You can also specify a group by appending a :, then the group or gid in the same way as you would for the chown(1) command (user:group).  If  a user is specified without a group, the primary GID for that user is used.  When using this option you must realize that the primary and supplemental  groups are set as well, even if the --group option is not specified.  The --group option is only for groups that the user isn't  normally  a  member  of  (like  adding  per  process   group membership for generic users like nobody).
of  this  executable.   The executable argument should be an absolute pathname.
run process as this group
print help information

alters  the  IO  scheduler  class and priority of the process before starting it (since version 1.15.0).   The  priority  can  be optionally  specified  by appending a : followed by the value.  The default priority is 4, unless class is  idle,  then  priority  will always  be  7.   The currently supported values for class are idle, best-effort and real-time.
referenced with  --pidfile and place the pid into it just before executing the process.  Note, the file will only be  removed  when  stopping  the program if --remove-pidfile is used.
The  process-name is  usually the process filename, but it could have been changed by the process itself.
add incr to the process' nice level

not  close any file descriptor when forcing the daemon into the background (since version 1.16.5).  Used for debugging purposes  to see  the process output, or to redirect file descriptors to log the process output.  Only relevant when using --background.

for  the  background process to send a readiness notification before considering the  service  started  (since  version  1.19.3). This  implements  parts  of  the  systemd  readiness  protocol,  as specified in the sd_notify(3) manual page.  The following variables are supported:
the  timeout  is reached, start-stop-daemon will exit with an error code, and no readiness notification  will  be  awaited.   The default is 60 seconds.
no  actions  are  (would  be) taken.
Only  relevant  when  using
for a process with the specified pid (since version 1.17.6). The pid must be a number greater than 0.
pid file to check
the  specified  parent  pid  ppid  (since version 1.17.7).  The ppid must be a number greater than 0.

alters  the  process  scheduler  policy  and  priority of the process before starting it (since version  1.15.0).   The  priority can be optionally specified by appending a : followed by the value. The  default  priority is 0.  The currently supported policy values are other, fifo and rr.
be more quiet
file (since  version  1.17.19).  This option will make start-stop-daemon remove the file referenced with  --pidfile  after  terminating  the process.

check  whether the  process(es)  do  finish.  It will check repeatedly whether any matching processes are running, until none are.  If  the  processes do  not  exit it will then take further action as determined by the schedule.
--stop,  specifies  the  signal  to  send  to processes being stopped (default TERM).
All matching processes will be sent the TERM signal (or the one specified via --signal or --retry) if
--start,  start  the  process  specified by pathname.  If not specified, defaults to the argument given to --exec.
get the program status
For daemons which have long-lived children which need to live through a --stop, you must specify a pidfile.
test mode, don't do anything
sets  the  umask  of  the  process  before starting it (since version 1.13.22).
process owner to check
be more verbose
print version
